results.title: Abraham Lincoln
results.creator_credit: Westinghouse Studio One, Donald Davis, Dorothy Mathews and Paul Nickell
results.brief_description: Television adaptation of English playwright and poet John Drinkwater’s play “Abraham Lincoln” which features a cameo role towards the end of the program by James Dean as a reluctant Union soldier sentenced to death for sleeping on guard duty. This live television drama documents a part of Lincoln’s life from his nomination for presidency through to his attendance at Ford’s Theater where his eventual assassination took place. Stars Robert Pastene as Abraham Lincoln and Judith Evelyn as Mary Lincoln. Also includes classic Westinghouse ad-breaks at intervals throughout the program. NB: Picture quality and sound is variable.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Westinghouse Studio One, Donald Davis, Dorothy Mathews and Paul Nickell

results.title:
Abra Cadabra
(1983)
Clips from film
results.brief_description: Australian cartoonist Alexander Stitt is best known for creating the ‘Life. Be in It’ advertisements, along with characters from the ‘Slip-Slop-Slap’ ads, but in 1983 he made the first 3D animated film, Abra Cadabra.
results.description: Three-dimensional stereoscopic images were invented in 1838, but it took 145 years for the first 3D animated feature to be made. Australian cartoonist Alexander Stitt is best known for creating the ‘Life. Be in It’ advertisements, along with characters from the ‘Slip-Slop-Slap’ ads, but in 1983 he made Abra Cadabra. This 3D cosmic fantasy stars John Farnham and Jacki Weaver in an adaptation of the Pied Piper story. It creates depth by using the Triangle 3D anaglyph system and special ‘AbraGoggles’ designed by Stitt. Unfortunately, the sale of Channel Nine meant the film wasn’t released, but it did screen on Nickelodeon in the 1980s and at film festivals.
description_for_label: Three-dimensional stereoscopic images were invented in 1838, but it took 145 years for the first 3D animated feature to be made. Australian cartoonist Alexander Stitt is best known for creating the ‘Life. Be in It’ advertisements, along with characters from the ‘Slip-Slop-Slap’ ads, but in 1983 he made Abra Cadabra. This 3D cosmic fantasy stars John Farnham and Jacki Weaver in an adaptation of the Pied Piper story. It creates depth by using the Triangle 3D anaglyph system and special ‘AbraGoggles’ designed by Stitt. Unfortunately, the sale of Channel Nine meant the film wasn’t released, but it did screen on Nickelodeon in the 1980s and at film festivals.

results.title: Abra Cadabra
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Donated by the Stitt Family
results.brief_description: Australian cartoonist Alexander Stitt is best known for creating the ‘Life. Be in It’ advertisements, along with characters from the ‘Slip-Slop-Slap’ ads, but in 1983 he made the first 3D animated film, Abra Cadabra.

constellations_primary.name: Storytime animated
constellations_primary.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

This 3D cosmic fantasy stars John Farnham and Jacki Weaver in an adaptation of the Pied Piper story. It creates depth by using the Triangle 3D anaglyph system and special ‘AbraGoggles’ designed by Stitt. Unfortunately, the sale of Channel Nine meant the film wasn’t released, but it did screen on Nickelodeon in the 1980s and at film festivals.

results.title: Above the timberline: the alpine tundra zone
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Hugh O'Connor, Tom Daly and J.V. Durden
results.brief_description: Remote and baffling except to the most daring climbers, the high peaks are worlds apart where only the most tenacious of living things endure. Forests give way to stunted vegetation and finally to the hardiest of plants adapted to withstand the rigours of bitter cold, glaring sun and tearing wind. The only animals found here are the wild, tough ones such as the mountain goat, elk and bighorn sheep. In true-life colour this film presents an account of life at this specialised level. Film award: Film Survey, Trieste, Italy.

results.title: Above the horizon
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Roman Kroitor, Hugh O'Connor and Tom Daly
results.brief_description: An exciting exploration of the weather and how man may one day learn to control it. For this film a great deal of extraordinary colour footage of the sky was put together, including a demonstration of rain-making. There are views of the geysers of the sun, of bright streamers of northern lights, of wind-stirred clouds, and even the awesome fury of a hurricane. Photography: Jean Roy Awards: Sydney, Buenos Aires, Padua, Canadian

results.title: Above the gorge
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission, Robert Horne and Ken Taylor
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wild Australia”.
Studies of the Wedge-tailed eagle, Australia’s largest bird, on the Nullarbor Plain in Western Australia, where CSIRO scientists are researching the life-cycle of the eagle, and in Western Victoria where it is regarded as an efficient controller of rabbits. Cinematographer: Keith Taylor.

results.title: Above the dust level [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Scarlett Pictures, Australian Film Commission, Kath Shelper and Carla Drago
results.brief_description: Set against a Sydney backdrop, a hypochondriac, her junkie ex-lover and a neighbour with a life threatening illness are united by dust, allergies and disappearing grey Y-fronts. Cast includes Jane Turner, Tobin Saunders and Melinda Dimitriades. (Awards: Winner of numerous awards, including Best Australian Short Comedy Award, MIFF 1999; Highly Commended, Melbourne Queer Film and Video Festival, 2000; Bronze Award, Houston Film Festival, 2000)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Scarlett Pictures, Australian Film Commission, Kath Shelper and Carla Drago

results.title: Above New Zealand
results.brief_description: Take a look at New Zealand as you have never seen it before. Soaring like a bird in low altitude light aircraft and helicopters, swooping down from the clouds occasionally to watch New Zealanders at work and at play. From your viewpoint in the sky you will see the natural forces that shaped New Zealand’s rugged beauty still at work reshaping the land. The history of New Zealand’s Maori and Pakeha peoples also comes vividly alive. Rated: G
